name: 文學作品導讀（一）

restrict: ◎限本系(含雙主修)、輔系修習◎限大一修習
goals: Learn key terms and concepts generally applied to the evaluation of literature
Hone skills of close reading and critical thinking
Develop curiosity about the world through context-specific analysis of literary works
Improve sensitivity to the English language
syllabus:
**Approaches to Literature**

National Taiwan Normal University, Fall 2022

Wednesdays, 13:20-15:10

Dr. Justin Prystash                                                 

Office:     Cheng 720                     

Office Hours: W 15:20-17:10; F 11:20-13:10; Virtual Meetings by Appointment

Email: jsprystash@gmail.com               

**Course Description**

This course provides students with an introduction to the study and appreciation of fiction, poetry, and drama. We will consider the basic elements of literature, such as plot and symbol, as well as the broader figurative meanings of literature. We will also approach literature from a historical perspective, covering the development of poetry from the Romantic to Modernist periods. 

**Texts**

I will provide PDFs of our readings.

**Assignments**

Attendance/Participation   20%

Group Responses              40%  

Final Exam                       40%

**Attendance/Participation**

Students are expected to regularly attend and contribute to class discussions and activities. 

**Group Responses**

Students will come together in groups to write responses to our reading for the day. Each response should be organized in a very specific way—I will discuss this in class and post instructions on Moodle. These group responses will help prepare you for the final exam, which is also a response. 

**Schedule**

Week 1, 9/7: Introduction and Syllabus Review

_Short Stories_

Week 2, 9/14: David Foster Wallace, “Everything is Green”

Week 3, 9/21: Kate Chopin, “The Story of an Hour”

Week 4, 9/28: John Updike, “A & P”; Group Response

Week 5, 10/5: Ambrose Bierce, “An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge”

Week 6, 10/12: Charlotte Perkins Gilman, “The Yellow Wallpaper” 

Week 7, 10/19: Raymond Carver, “Cathedral”

Week 8, 10/26: Yasunari Kawabata, “The Grasshopper and the Bell Cricket”; Group Response

_Drama Interlude_

Week 9, 11/2: Susan Glaspell, _Trifles_

_Poetry: Romantics, Victorians, Modernists_

Week 10, 11/9: William Blake, from _Songs of Innocence and of Experience_

Week 11, 11/16: William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge, from _Lyrical Ballads_

Week 12, 11/23: Matthew Arnold, “Dover Beach”; Group Response 

Week 13, 11/30: Robert Browning, “My Last Duchess” and Alfred, Lord Tennyson, “Ulysses” 

Week 14, 12/7: T. S. Eliot, “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock”

_Finale_

Week 15, 12/14: Music Lyrics as Poetry

Week 16, 12/21: Final Exam
